newsitem.title: USA: Calif. officials back privately funded prison plan.
newsitem.headline: Calif. officials back privately funded prison plan.

text.p: California state and local officials on Thursday announced an agreement with Corrections Corporation of America to build a privately funded and managed prison in Kern County.
Corrections Corporation of America will finance, design, build and operate the 2,000-bed facility in California City.
The company said the medium security prison would cost $80 million to $100 million to build. Once in operation, it would charge California's Department of Corrections to house state prisoners.
The project is expected to create 375 to 400 new jobs in California City and up to 1,300 jobs in Kern County.

"Runaway prison costs are cannibalizing our state budget," said state Senator Richard Polanco. "The solution is public/private partnerships which take the capital costs off the public rolls and transfer the costs of start-up and operation to the private company running the facility."
Corrections Corporation of America operates jails and prisons for government agencies in the U.S., Puerto Rico and Australia.
